item.title: Prep For Okami 2 With This Deal For Nearly 60% Off Okami HD On PC
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/prep-for-okami-2-with-this-deal-for-nearly-60-off-okami-hd-on-pc/1100-6528465/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Nearly 20 years after its release, Okami is getting a sequel. The project was announced during The Game Awards, and while we still don’t have a specific release date or platforms, Hideki Kamiya is confirmed to be spearheading the game. That means you have plenty of time to play through the original in anticipation of Okami 2, and right now, you can grab the Steam version of Okami HD for just $8.59 (was $20) on Fanatical. This deal expires on December 25, so you only have a couple of weeks to cash in on the offer.

Though Okami was originally launched on PS2 in 2006, it was remastered and released as Okami HD on various platforms, including a port to PC in 2017. Okami HD kept the game’s iconic sumi-e ink art style intact while enhancing the game with HD visuals, making this the definitive version to play in 2024. Okami takes about 30 hours to complete--but with no launch date revealed for Okami 2, you should have plenty of time to explore its memorable world.

Along with your purchase, you also get a 5%-off coupon code to use on your next Fanatical purchase.

Looking for even more PC deals? Check out Fanatical’s Winter Sale, which includes massive discounts on Helldivers 2, Balatro, Dragon’s Dogma 2, and more.

Disclosure: GameSpot and Fanatical are both owned by Fandom.

item.title: The Witcher 4 Director Breaks Down New Trailer Scene-By-Scene
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-witcher-4-director-breaks-down-new-trailer-scene-by-scene/1100-6528474/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

One of the highlights of The Game Awards was the reveal of the first teaser trailer for The Witcher 4, the long-awaited sequel to The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt. Now, the game's director, Sebastian Kalemba, has shared some insights about the upcoming sequel in a scene-by-scene breakdown of the teaser.

Kalemba confirmed that the events of this teaser are a part of The Witcher 4's story, and not merely a one-off creation for the trailer. He set the stage for the unfolding tragedy by revealing that the scenes are set in Stromford, an "isolated village up north." This part of the continent doesn't rely on Witchers to hunt their monsters. Instead, a young woman from the village has been chosen to be a ritual sacrifice.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: The Witcher IV – Official Cinematic Reveal Trailer Breakdown

The girl in question is named Mioni, and her family and the townspeople aren't the only ones using her. Kalemba states that Ciri is also using Mioni as bait by allowing her to sing the song that summons the monster, the Bauk. However, Ciri isn't willing to risk Mioni's life after that, so she sends her back to the village before the fight with the Bauk begins.

Unfortunately for Ciri, her hard-fought battle against the Bauk appears to be for nothing when she discovers that Mioni has been murdered by the townspeople. Intriguingly, Kalemba suggested that there is a way to save Mioni from her fate. He then hinted at choices and the resulting consequences for those decisions. So perhaps it's possible to slay the monster and keep Mioni alive. Or maybe the cost of Mioni's survival means the Bauk must be spared. We can only speculate for now.

Kalemba also recently explained how Cyberpunk 2077's difficult development has inspired CD Projekt Red to make beneficial changes to the way The Witcher 4 is being developed. The team has teased that The Witcher 4 will be "bigger and better" than both Cyberpunk 2077 and The Witcher 3. It's currently unknown when The Witcher 4 will be released, as the project only recently ramped up its team to over 400 developers and began full production.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: New Deepest Fear Trailer Shows Off More Of The Metroidvania Horror Game In Action
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/new-deepest-fear-trailer-shows-off-more-of-the-metroidvania-horror-game-in-action/1100-6528410/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

A new trailer for Deepest Fear has gone live, showing off more of the game's '80s Hollywood horror vibe. The world premiere for Deepest Fear was seen during the PC Gaming Show last week, and this is the first look at the gameplay of Deepest Fear revealed more details about the game and the monstrous creatures that will plague players as they explore a flooded deep-sea facility.

Developed by Variable State--the studio behind games like Last Stop and Virginia--Deepest Fear puts players in the shoes of Dr. Danni Carroll as she way fights her way to the heart of a sinister project that could have dire consequences for humanity.

Inspired by classic horror and action films like The Abyss, The Thing, The Fly, and Total Recall, the game has a retro-future art direction combined with a metroidvania level design. Throw in mutilated bodies, all manner of organic nastiness, and some wonderfully analogue technology, and you've got a game that looks like it was pulled straight from a David Cronenberg film set.

The environment of the Neptune facility that players will explore is full of nightmarish entities, which can potentially emerge from any water source or submerged space. Essentially, if there's a puddle or a body of water, something nasty and homicidal is lurking in it and is ready to give you a jump-scare.

To make things more challenging, the facility is prone to flooding and you'll have to make use of your wits and an arsenal of tools to uncover the mysteries of lurking set seven miles under the ocean. A release date for Deepest Fear hasn't been announced yet, and so far, it has only been confirmed for PC.

Darryn Bonthuys on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Preorders For Anime-Inspired Racing Game Screamer Now Available
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/preorders-for-anime-inspired-racing-game-screamer-now-available/1100-6528471/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The classic arcade game, Screamer, is getting new life in 2026 as an anime-inspired racing game. Developer Milestone revealed a stylish trailer during The Game Awards--and while it didn’t show off any gameplay, it looks like the studio is drawing heavily from manga and anime to craft a racing game with multiple character arcs and a nuanced storyline. Troy Baker--voice actor from The Last of Us--is also said to be involved. If you’re excited about seeing how Milestone reimagines this popular 1995 arcade game, preorders are now available at Amazon and Best Buy.

Screamer Preorder Bonuses

No preorder bonuses are available for Screamer. The game was just announced and isn't launching until some time in 2026, so it's possible preorder bonuses could be announced eventually. We’ll be sure to update this article if anything new is revealed.

Screamer will be receiving additional support from Polygon Pictures, as the animation studio is creating a variety of cutscenes for the game. Polygon Pictures previously worked on projects like Tron: Uprising, Transformers Prime, and Pacific Rim: The Black.

There’s still a lot we don’t know about the upcoming game, so be sure to stay tuned for more details--including a full gameplay reveal.

item.title: Elden Ring Nightreign Network Test Offers An Early Opportunity To Return To The Lands Between
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/elden-ring-nightreign-network-test-offers-an-early-opportunity-to-return-to-the-lands-between/1100-6528472/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

From Software made a major splash at The Game Awards with Elden Right Nightreign, a standalone co-op survival game in the Elden Ring universe set to launch in 2025. Eager Tarnished looking to take on this new challenge won't have to wait long, however, as Bandai Namco and From Software have announced a network test for soon after the new year rings in.

The network test is slated for February 2025, though exact dates and times have not been announced. Interested players can sign up for the test and the platform of their choice--PlayStation 5 or Xbox Series X|S--beginning January 10.

The test "is a preliminary verification test" where players will be provided a "portion" of the game, according to the Nightreign website. The number of players that will be chosen has not been disclosed, though the website also mentioned "large-scale network load tests."

Elden Ring Nightring is a departure from the original game and its expansion, Shadow Of The Erdtree, as it focuses on co-op and speed rather than a single-player experience. Players will slowly level up by defeating enemies and finding gear, before taking on a major foe together at the end of each challenge.

The new Elden Ring was one of many surprises unveiled during The Game Awards last night. Other big reveals include multiple returning franchises--with Okami, Virtua Fighter, Onimusha, and Ninja Gaiden among them--as well as Project Robot, the next adventure from Ico creator Fumito Ueda and his team at genDesign.

Elden Ring Nightreign will launch in 2025 for Xbox Series X|S, Xbox One, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, and PC.

Jason Fanelli on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: The Office Comes To Funko Fusion Today With New DLC
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-office-comes-to-funko-fusion-today-with-new-dlc/1100-6528448/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

10:10 Games has announced a partnership with NBC's The office for an unexpected crossover collaboration in Funko Fusion. The Office Cameo Pack DLC, as it's called, introduces four characters from the popular comedy series--Michael, Dwight, Jim, and Pam--and each has their own unique weapons and skills.

The DLC also includes a special level that allows players to make their way through a recreation of the iconic Dunder Mifflin office in Scranton, PA, featuring a number of Easter eggs and references. The level is inspired by the Season 5 episode Stress Relief Part 1, with players having to make their way through Dwight's fire drill prank with the aim of saving Pam.

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Funko Fusion - Official The Office DLC Intro Trailer

You can check out the announcement trailer below, which riffs on The Office's iconic intro.

The Office Cameo Pack is available today for $10 USD on PS5, PS4, Xbox Series X|S, and PC (no mention was made of Xbox One), with a launch for Switch set for 2025. It's just the latest DLC pack for the game, following the recent debut of the Wicked DLC tied to the movie's release. More updates are coming in 2025.

Funko Fusion launched in September 2024 and features characters from a bunch of different Universal film and TV franchises, including Back to the Future, Battlestar Galactica, Jaws, Jurassic World, The Walking Dead, The Mummy, and, as mentioned, Wicked. The game also features Colonel Sanders of KFC fame because why not.

As for The Office TV series, the American version ended in 2013, but a reboot of sorts called The Paper is in the works for Peacock. Domhnall Gleeson and Sabrina Impacciatore will star on the show. While you wait, you can check out the newly released Australian version of The Office.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
